articles.title: Press release - Gender equality week: closing the gender talent gap
articles.summary: From 3 to 7 November 2025, EP committees will be discussing how to harness women’s talent through education, training and employment, to drive economic growth and progress.Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
Under the overarching topic of “Talent”, the sixth European Gender Equality Week will feature several committee debates and events, focusing on closing the gender talent gap in education and creating conditions where women can thrive. It will highlight equality – not just as a matter of fairness, but as a driver of economic growth and progress, by using women’s talent to the full.

Quotes

Ahead of the week, Antonella Sberna (ECR, Italy), European Parliament Vice-President responsible for Gender Equality Week, said: “The future of Europe depends on our ability to nurture talent: from classrooms to boardrooms, from laboratories to parliaments, Europe must become a place where every talent can flourish. Our task is to break down all those barriers that should no longer exist.”

Lina Gálvez (S&D, Spain), Chair of the Women’s Rights and Gender Equality Committee, added: “Talent is equally spread, opportunities are not. Let's challenge that. The time for equality is now.”

High-level discussion on the gender talent gap

On Tuesday 4 November 2025, from 16.00 to 18.00, a high-level event on Facing the talent gap. Creating the conditions for every talent to shine will be hosted by EP Vice-President Antonella Sberna, in cooperation with Women’s Rights and Gender Equality Committee Chair Lina Gálvez. Participants will include: Henna Virkkunen, Executive Vice-President of the European Commission for Tech Sovereignty, Security and Democracy; Michaela Benthaus, space engineer and currently a young graduate trainee at the European Space Agency (ESA); Solange Fugger, an emergency medicine consultant at the Santo Spirito, Aurelia and Belcolle Hospitals in Rome; Johanna Pirker, computer scientist, educator, and game designer at Graz University of Technology, and professor at Munich’s Ludwig Maximilian University; Lella Golfo, president of Fondazione Bellisario; and Isabelle Le Galo Flores, Secretary-General of the European Economic and Social Committee.

You can follow the event live here.

On Wednesday 5 November from 10.30 - 12.00, Parliament’s President Roberta Metsola will take part in a public hearing in the Women’s Rights and Gender Equality Committee on Women’s Leadership in Politics.

A panel discussion will follow, with: Dr Maja Herman, psychiatrist, psychotherapist and art therapist; Joanna Burnos, founder of the LEADERIS Institute, entrepreneur and investor; Orla O’Connor, former Director of the Irish National Women’s Council (remote participation); and Dr Zahra Runderkamp, from the political alliance “Stem op een vrouw” (vote for a woman).

Read more about these and other events and follow them live on the EP’s Multimedia Centre website.

Background

Every year, the European Parliament hosts Gender Equality Week to assess progress, highlight achievements, and identify new ways to promote the rights of women and girls and achieve gender equality. The events are organised by Parliament's committees, delegations, political groups, and administration. The week was first launched in 2020 by the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality.

articles.title: Wikimedia Community Ireland and Rising Voices collaborate for a Gaeilge language digital activism workshop at the National Library of Ireland
articles.summary: Rising Voices teamed up with Wikimedia Ireland Community for a one-day workshop to create a roadmap for the Irish language online.
articles.content:
The following article is republished as part of a collaboration with Wikimedia Community Ireland and was originally published on their website on July 28, 2025.

On July 14, 2025, Wikimedia Community Ireland hosted a Rising Voices Digital Activism Workshop for 20 participants at the National Library of Ireland.

Those in attendance included a range of stakeholders from the Irish language media and technology community. We were joined by educators, representatives from Conradh na Gaeilge (a social and cultural organisation which promotes the Irish language in Ireland and worldwide), Tuarisc.ie, GaelGoer, ADAPT’s eSTÓR project team (aimed to improve machine translation and promote digital language equality in Europe), Raidió na Life, Raidió Rí-Rá, along with Irish language content creators.

Open knowledge is important for maintaining inclusivity, accessibility and diversity in the information we consume. It plays a key role in helping to dismantle a society in which certain traditions, beliefs, voices, heritage, ethnicities, or languages are valued or dominant over others.

Consequently, Irish language outreach is a key element of our work. Vicipéid, the Irish language Wikipedia, offers a valuable place for the Irish language to thrive in a community setting in the digital space. We were delighted to join Rising Voices’ international collaboration to co-host the workshop with the National Library of Ireland.

About Rising Voices and the UNESCO Digital Activism Toolkit

Rising Voices is a Global Voices outreach project that supports underrepresented communities who want to tell their own stories using digital media. Fifty percent of today’s spoken languages will be extinct or seriously endangered by 2100. Irish is considered to be at risk of digital extinction and was listed by the UNESCO Atlas of the World’s Languages in Danger as “definitely endangered.”

For the International Decade of Indigenous Languages 2022 to 2032 Rising Voices and a range of collaborators worked together to create the UNESCO Digital Initiatives for Minority Languages toolkit. The toolkit illustrates how the internet and other digital tools can be utilised to conserve and promote Indigenous languages and was the basis of the workshop.

Indigenous, endangered, and low-resource languages all have unique contexts, needs, and different resources available to them; thus, it is important to understand the local context. Grassroots action is key to achieving impactful, meaningful change. Action needs to be informed by experience and local knowledge, or in other words, those who are actively using the language in the digital space.

The Rising Voices Digital Activism Workshop

The schedule of the day was jam-packed with passionate presentations, interactive sessions, group Q&As, and panel discussions. Although a bilingual event, most attendees opted to use their Irish throughout the event, which had an open and warm atmosphere, instilling confidence in each participant’s language skills.

The day kicked off with a panel discussion with Maitiú Ó Coimín (Tuairisc.ie) and Róisín Ní Mhaoláin (Raidió na Life) on how digitisation has changed the landscape of media. Nóirín Ní Bhraoin, co-founder of the GaelGoer app (the first communications app in the Irish language), also presented. Cassie Ní Chatháin and Kate Ní Dhubhlaoich from Conradh na Gaeilge presented on Irish language activism initiatives and community organising.

Dr. Abigail Walsh from ADAPTs eSTÓR Project presented alongside her colleagues Mark Andrade and Bláithín Heffernan. They presented their current work on data curation using Vicipéid data. The project aims to develop key resources for Irish Machine Translation (EC) and ensure high-quality processing of Irish digital text data, which is vital for Digital Language Equality.

The post-presentation discussion highlighted the rift between the technological tools that are available for minority and majority languages, along with how powerful they have the potential to be in elevating the language in the digital space.

Content creation offers a launchpad for digital activism

Irish language content creators Laura Pakenham and Cúán de Búrca also presented. Their Irish language content serves as prime examples of how we can use social media platforms to promote the use of minority languages in our everyday lives.

Pakenham inspires users to implement Irish into their everyday language. She spoke about overcoming imposter syndrome and emphasised how mistakes can only lead to learning. She often posts vlog-style videos of her going about her day in Galway, but using Irish in her everyday interactions, like buying a coffee or popping to the shops. Her inspirational content is based on the ethos that instead of being intimidated by a lack of fluency, we should focus on the words we do have and make simple everyday switches.

Content creator and podcaster, De Búrca emphasised that revitalising minority languages starts with a community, which can be “as simple as two people speaking Irish rather than English.”

He also mentioned “the Kneecap effect” and how Irish is trending. However, he emphasized that engaging with the Irish language on a deeper level can lead to a richer experience of our linguistic heritage.

Both speakers provided the audience with some insights into content creation as Gaeilge on TikTok. They shared just how important small details like understanding how to increase engagement and cultivate your audience can be powerful skills for digital activism.

Workshop outcomes: TREORCHLÁR – ROADMAP

After the presentations, participants worked together to come up with a roadmap for digital activism for Irish. This roadmap outlines the current landscape, challenges, tools, goals, and collective vision for the future of the Irish language in digital and community contexts. It highlights a growing interest and pride in Irish among the public, though this is met with limited resources, government disengagement, and a lack of supportive infrastructure.

Major challenges include insufficient funding, time, and understanding of community needs, as well as a shortage of accessible digital tools in Irish. The roadmap envisions a future where Irish is widely spoken, visible in public and online spaces, supported by strong digital tools like translation apps and AI technologies, and integrated into everyday life, education, and services. Ultimately, the dream is for Irish to be a living, thriving language, used confidently across all aspects of society.

The next steps for the Rising Voice Digital Activism Initiative are to bring the results of the discussions and roadmap to those involved with the Government’s Irish Language support schemes Action Plan, for delivery of the Digital Plan for the Irish Language.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a meaningful, organized effort to preserve and promote the endangered Irish language through digital activism, involving diverse stakeholders and producing a concrete roadmap. This initiative supports cultural and linguistic diversity, addresses digital language equality, and has broad societal significance beyond a niche group. The detailed workshop content and planned next steps demonstrate substantive impact and hope for revitalizing a minority language.
articles.personality_title: Irish language supporters create a digital plan to boost Gaeilge online
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Irish language, also called Gaeilge, is spoken less today and is considered endangered by UNESCO. To help keep it alive, groups focused on language and technology joined forces to plan ways to use the internet and digital tools to promote Irish.

**What happened** – On July 14, 2025, Wikimedia Community Ireland and Rising Voices held a workshop at the National Library of Ireland. Twenty people from Irish media, education, and tech, including creators and language activists, came together. They shared ideas, learned about digital tools, and worked on a roadmap to support Irish online. Presentations covered topics like digital media changes, language apps, machine translation, and content creation on social media.

**Impact** – This workshop is special because it brought many parts of the Irish language community together to plan real actions. It showed how digital tools can help a language that risks disappearing online. Creators shared how using Irish in everyday videos and podcasts can encourage others to speak it. The roadmap they made points out challenges, like not enough funding or digital tools, but also sets clear goals to make Irish more visible and easy to use on the internet.

**What's next step** – The team will share their roadmap with the government groups responsible for supporting the Irish language. This will help shape official plans to improve digital support for Irish. The hope is that these efforts will lead to better tools, more online content, and stronger use of Irish in daily life.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A group of Irish language supporters created a detailed digital plan to help make Gaeilge stronger and more visible on the internet.

Vingt personnes venues des médias irlandais, de l’éducation et de la technologie, y compris des créateurs et des militants de la langue, se sont réunies. Elles ont partagé des idées, découvert des outils numériques et travaillé sur une feuille de route pour soutenir l’irlandais en ligne. Les présentations portaient sur les changements dans les médias numériques, les applications linguistiques, la traduction automatique et la création de contenu sur les réseaux sociaux.

**Impact** – Cet atelier est spécial car il a rassemblé plusieurs acteurs de la communauté irlandaise pour planifier des actions concrètes. Il a montré comment les outils numériques peuvent aider une langue qui risque de disparaître en ligne. Les créateurs ont expliqué comment utiliser l’irlandais dans des vidéos et podcasts quotidiens peut encourager d’autres personnes à le parler. La feuille de route identifie des défis, comme le manque de financement ou d’outils numériques, mais fixe aussi des objectifs clairs pour rendre l’irlandais plus visible et plus facile à utiliser sur Internet.

**Prochaine étape** – L’équipe va partager sa feuille de route avec les groupes gouvernementaux responsables du soutien à la langue irlandaise. Cela aidera à élaborer des plans officiels pour améliorer le soutien numérique au Gaeilge. L’espoir est que ces efforts mènent à de meilleurs outils, plus de contenu en ligne et un usage renforcé de l’irlandais dans la vie quotidienne.

**Phrase clé** – Un groupe de défenseurs de la langue irlandaise a créé un plan numérique détaillé pour rendre le Gaeilge plus fort et plus visible sur Internet.

articles.title: Measure of Justice for Windrush Victims
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Thomas Tobierre, 69, who applied to the Home Office’s Windrush Compensation Scheme as a primary applicant, says he realized that the scheme was set up to deny claimants their right to an effective remedy.
                    © 2023 Ellie Kealey for Human Rights Watch 
          
    


  
On October 24, the UK government announced long-awaited reforms to the Windrush Compensation Scheme that address some—but not all—long-standing concerns related to older claimants who had lost their private pensions due to government wrongdoing. Many died before receiving owed compensation.The government launched the scheme in 2019 to compensate members and relatives of immigrants, mostly from Caribbean and other Commonwealth countries, known as the Windrush generation for wrongfully treating them like illegal immigrants. Tens of thousands lost their jobs, pensions, access to health care, and other basic rights—some even faced deportation and detention—because the government hadn’t provided them with papers to prove their legal status in the UK.The changes include paying Windrush claimants, who challenge a compensation offer, up to 75 percent of the award in advance, pending the review of their offer. The scheme also now compensates people for private and occupational pension losses, reflecting the fact that claimants were forced to withdraw money from their pension to support themselves. Priority will be given to applications from claimants 75 and older and those with serious health conditions.These changes partially address recommendations from civil society, the Windrush commissioner, and the Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman including in a recent case ruling.Thomas Tobierre, a Windrush claimant affected by pension losses, told Human Rights Watch that he first found out about the changes through the media.Since publishing research in 2023 on rights abuses arising from the compensation scheme. Human Rights Watch has continued to work closely alongside campaigners, civil society, and lawyers.Human Rights Watch remains deeply concerned about the government’s continued denial of free legal representation for Windrush claimants. Lawyers showed that claimants needed legal support to meet the complex requirements to provide evidence to substantiate their claims.The Windrush commissioner said that members of the Windrush generation are concerned about anti-immigrant polarization in the UK. He said that officials need to consider the human impacts of immigration policy changes to avoid future Windrush scandals.If the Labour government is serious about righting wrongs of the past and honoring the contributions of the Windrush generation, it should grant free legal representation to Windrush claimants to give them the best shot at full and fair compensation.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Thomas Tobierre, 69, who applied to the Home Office’s Windrush Compensation Scheme as a primary applicant, says he realized that the scheme was set up to deny claimants their right to an effective remedy. © 2023 Ellie Kealey for Human Rights Watch

On October 24, the UK government announced long-awaited reforms to the Windrush Compensation Scheme that address some—but not all—long-standing concerns related to older claimants who had lost their private pensions due to government wrongdoing. Many died before receiving owed compensation.

The government launched the scheme in 2019 to compensate members and relatives of immigrants, mostly from Caribbean and other Commonwealth countries, known as the Windrush generation for wrongfully treating them like illegal immigrants. Tens of thousands lost their jobs, pensions, access to health care, and other basic rights—some even faced deportation and detention—because the government hadn’t provided them with papers to prove their legal status in the UK.

The changes include paying Windrush claimants, who challenge a compensation offer, up to 75 percent of the award in advance, pending the review of their offer. The scheme also now compensates people for private and occupational pension losses, reflecting the fact that claimants were forced to withdraw money from their pension to support themselves. Priority will be given to applications from claimants 75 and older and those with serious health conditions.

These changes partially address recommendations from civil society, the Windrush commissioner, and the Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman including in a recent case ruling.

Thomas Tobierre, a Windrush claimant affected by pension losses, told Human Rights Watch that he first found out about the changes through the media.

Since publishing research in 2023 on rights abuses arising from the compensation scheme. Human Rights Watch has continued to work closely alongside campaigners, civil society, and lawyers.

Human Rights Watch remains deeply concerned about the government’s continued denial of free legal representation for Windrush claimants. Lawyers showed that claimants needed legal support to meet the complex requirements to provide evidence to substantiate their claims.

The Windrush commissioner said that members of the Windrush generation are concerned about anti-immigrant polarization in the UK. He said that officials need to consider the human impacts of immigration policy changes to avoid future Windrush scandals.

If the Labour government is serious about righting wrongs of the past and honoring the contributions of the Windrush generation, it should grant free legal representation to Windrush claimants to give them the best shot at full and fair compensation.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on significant UK government reforms to the Windrush Compensation Scheme that provide tangible benefits to a historically marginalized group by addressing pension losses and advancing partial payments. These changes represent meaningful progress in rectifying past injustices faced by the Windrush generation, impacting a broad public demographic and reflecting ongoing advocacy efforts. While some concerns remain, the reforms mark a hopeful step toward justice and recognition of human rights.
articles.personality_title: UK government improves compensation for Windrush generation pension losses
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Windrush generation includes people who came to the UK mainly from Caribbean countries and other Commonwealth nations. Many were wrongly treated as illegal immigrants because the government did not give them papers to prove their legal status. This caused them to lose jobs, pensions, and access to services. In 2019, the UK government created the Windrush Compensation Scheme to pay these individuals and their families for the harm caused.

**What happened** – On October 24, 2023, the UK government announced changes to the Windrush Compensation Scheme. Now, people who challenge their compensation offer can receive up to 75% of the payment early, while their case is reviewed. The scheme also started to include compensation for private and work pensions that claimants lost, because some had to use their pensions to live. Older claimants, especially those over 75 or with serious health problems, will get priority when applying.

**Impact** – These changes help fix some problems that claimants faced, especially older people who lost pensions and sometimes died before getting money they were owed. The early payment option makes the process faster and less stressful. It also shows the government is listening to advice from groups helping the Windrush generation. Still, some issues remain, like the need for free legal help, which many claimants need to prove their cases.

**What's next step** – Campaigners and groups want the government to provide free legal support to claimants. This would help people understand and meet the complicated rules to get full compensation. Officials are also urged to think carefully about how immigration policies affect people’s lives to avoid repeating past mistakes.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UK government has improved the Windrush Compensation Scheme by addressing pension losses and speeding up payments, offering fairer support to those affected.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le gouvernement britannique améliore la compensation des pertes de retraite de la génération Windrush
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La génération Windrush regroupe des personnes venues principalement des Caraïbes et d’autres pays du Commonwealth. Beaucoup ont été à tort considérées comme des immigrés illégaux parce que le gouvernement ne leur a pas fourni de papiers prouvant leur statut légal. Cela leur a fait perdre leur emploi, leur retraite et l’accès aux services. En 2019, le gouvernement britannique a créé le régime de compensation Windrush pour indemniser ces personnes et leurs familles.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 24 octobre 2023, le gouvernement britannique a annoncé des modifications du régime de compensation Windrush. Désormais, les personnes qui contestent leur offre de compensation peuvent recevoir jusqu’à 75 % du montant en avance, pendant que leur dossier est examiné. Le régime indemnise aussi les pertes de retraites privées et professionnelles, car certains ont dû utiliser leur retraite pour vivre. Les demandeurs âgés, surtout ceux de plus de 75 ans ou en mauvaise santé, seront prioritaires.

**Impact** – Ces changements corrigent certains problèmes rencontrés par les demandeurs, en particulier les personnes âgées ayant perdu leur retraite et parfois décédées avant de recevoir leur indemnisation. Le paiement anticipé rend le processus plus rapide et moins stressant. Cela montre aussi que le gouvernement écoute les recommandations des groupes aidant la génération Windrush. Toutefois, certains problèmes restent, comme le besoin d’une aide juridique gratuite.

**Prochaines étapes** – Les défenseurs demandent au gouvernement de fournir une aide juridique gratuite aux demandeurs. Cela les aiderait à comprendre et à respecter les règles complexes pour obtenir une compensation complète. Les responsables sont aussi invités à réfléchir aux effets des politiques migratoires sur la vie des gens pour éviter de répéter les erreurs passées.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le gouvernement britannique a amélioré le régime de compensation Windrush en prenant en compte les pertes de retraite et en accélérant les paiements, offrant un meilleur soutien aux personnes concernées.
articles.personality_title_es: El gobierno británico mejora la compensación por pérdidas de pensiones de la generación Windrush
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La generación Windrush incluye a personas que llegaron al Reino Unido principalmente desde países del Caribe y otras naciones de la Commonwealth. Muchas fueron tratadas erróneamente como inmigrantes ilegales porque el gobierno no les dio documentos para probar su estatus legal. Esto les hizo perder empleos, pensiones y acceso a servicios. En 2019, el gobierno creó el Esquema de Compensación Windrush para pagar a estas personas y sus familias por los daños sufridos.

**Qué pasó** – El 24 de octubre de 2023, el gobierno británico anunció cambios en el Esquema de Compensación Windrush. Ahora, las personas que cuestionen su oferta de compensación pueden recibir hasta el 75 % del pago por adelantado mientras revisan su caso. El esquema también comenzó a incluir compensación por las pensiones privadas y laborales que perdieron, porque algunos tuvieron que usar sus pensiones para vivir. Los solicitantes mayores, especialmente los mayores de 75 años o con problemas graves de salud, tendrán prioridad.

**Impacto** – Estos cambios ayudan a resolver algunos problemas que enfrentaban los solicitantes, especialmente las personas mayores que perdieron sus pensiones y a veces murieron antes de recibir el dinero que les correspondía. La opción de pago anticipado hace que el proceso sea más rápido y menos estresante. También muestra que el gobierno escucha las recomendaciones de los grupos que apoyan a la generación Windrush. Sin embargo, aún quedan problemas, como la necesidad de ayuda legal gratuita.

**Próximo paso** – Los activistas y grupos piden al gobierno que ofrezca apoyo legal gratuito a los solicitantes. Esto ayudaría a las personas a entender y cumplir las reglas complicadas para obtener la compensación completa. También se insta a los funcionarios a considerar cómo las políticas migratorias afectan la vida de las personas para evitar repetir errores del pasado.

**Resumen en una frase** – El gobierno del Reino Unido ha mejorado el Esquema de Compensación Windrush al abordar las pérdidas de pensiones y acelerar los pagos, ofreciendo un apoyo más justo a los afectados.

articles.title: Eurobarometer: Austrians donate a lot
articles.summary: A recently presented Eurobarometer study deals with the question of how Europeans view the social economy and how they engage themselves. In Austria, donations are made more frequently than average.
articles.content:
A recently presented Eurobarometer study deals with the question of how Europeans view the social economy and how they engage themselves. In Austria, donations are made more frequently than average.

Brussels (APA) – According to a Eurobarometer survey published on Tuesday, 75 percent of Europeans value the importance of the social economy for the societal well-being of their country. The majority supports political measures to promote it. Austrians are above average engaged in social issues; for instance, two-thirds of those surveyed there have donated in the last five years, compared to 18 percent across the EU.

Half of the respondents across the EU and significantly more than half in Austria have engaged in the social economy in the last five years, through activities such as volunteering (18 percent EU-wide, 15 percent Austria), donations (18 percent to 35 percent), or as members (13 percent each). One in three people in the EU receives support from the social economy in areas such as education, training, and housing. This survey counts charitable, cultural, and sports non-profit organizations as part of the social economy. According to the EU Commission, it employs around 11.5 million people across the EU.

Important Role in Child, Elderly, and Disability Care

The awareness of the social economy varies significantly between member states: about half of all EU citizens have heard of the social economy (from 82 percent in Malta to 34 percent in Greece). Austria is at exactly 50 percent, which is the EU average. Half of EU citizens and nearly two-thirds of citizens in Austria believe that the social economy sector is well developed in their country. Nevertheless, 88 percent demand that their country’s authorities implement strategies and laws to support social economy organizations.

The role of this sector is considered most important in child, elderly, and disability care (58 percent EU, 61 percent Austria), education (44 and 46 percent respectively), as well as culture and sports (42 and 55 percent respectively). A full 93 percent of people demand that companies align with social values, prioritize social and ecological goals, redistribute profits, and operate with democratic governance structures. 26,420 people were surveyed across the EU for this Eurobarometer in May 2025. (28.10.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant and positive societal trend where a large portion of Europeans, especially Austrians, actively support and engage in the social economy through donations and volunteering. This engagement promotes social well-being, care for vulnerable groups, and democratic governance, reflecting broad public support for social and ecological values. The study provides detailed data and highlights the importance of social economy organizations, which have a meaningful impact on society at large.
articles.personality_title: Austrians lead Europe in donating to support social causes
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – A recent Eurobarometer survey studied how people across Europe view and take part in the social economy, which includes charities, cultural groups, and sports organizations.

**What happened** – The survey found that in Austria, about two-thirds of people donated money in the last five years, much higher than the 18 percent average across the European Union (EU). Many Austrians also volunteer or join social groups. The survey included over 26,000 people across the EU and was published in October 2025.

**Impact** – This shows Austrians are especially active in helping their communities through donations and volunteering. The social economy supports important services like care for children, elderly, and people with disabilities. Most Europeans agree that companies should focus on social and environmental goals, not just profits.

**What's next step** – Almost 90 percent of people want their governments to create laws and strategies that support social economy organizations. This could lead to stronger rules and more resources to help charities and similar groups grow.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Austrians donate and volunteer more than most Europeans, showing strong support for social causes and community care.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les Autrichiens en tête des dons pour soutenir les causes sociales en Europe
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Une récente enquête Eurobaromètre a étudié comment les Européens perçoivent et participent à l’économie sociale, qui comprend les associations caritatives, culturelles et sportives.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’enquête montre qu’en Autriche, environ deux tiers des personnes ont fait un don au cours des cinq dernières années, bien plus que la moyenne de 18 % dans l’Union européenne (UE). De nombreux Autrichiens font aussi du bénévolat ou adhèrent à des groupes sociaux. Plus de 26 000 personnes de l’UE ont été interrogées, et les résultats ont été publiés en octobre 2025.

**Impact** – Cela montre que les Autrichiens sont particulièrement actifs pour aider leurs communautés par des dons et du bénévolat. L’économie sociale soutient des services importants comme les soins aux enfants, aux personnes âgées et aux personnes handicapées. La plupart des Européens pensent que les entreprises doivent se concentrer sur des objectifs sociaux et environnementaux, pas seulement sur les profits.

**Prochaine étape** – Près de 90 % des personnes souhaitent que leurs gouvernements créent des lois et des stratégies pour soutenir les organisations de l’économie sociale. Cela pourrait renforcer les règles et les ressources pour aider ces associations à se développer.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Les Autrichiens donnent et font du bénévolat plus que la plupart des Européens, montrant un fort soutien aux causes sociales et aux soins communautaires.
articles.personality_title_es: Los austríacos lideran Europa en donaciones para apoyar causas sociales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Una encuesta reciente de Eurobarómetro estudió cómo las personas en Europa ven y participan en la economía social, que incluye organizaciones benéficas, culturales y deportivas.

**Qué pasó** – La encuesta encontró que en Austria, alrededor de dos tercios de las personas donaron dinero en los últimos cinco años, mucho más que el promedio del 18 por ciento en la Unión Europea (UE). Muchos austríacos también hacen voluntariado o se unen a grupos sociales. La encuesta incluyó a más de 26,000 personas en la UE y se publicó en octubre de 2025.

**Impacto** – Esto muestra que los austríacos son especialmente activos para ayudar a sus comunidades mediante donaciones y voluntariado. La economía social apoya servicios importantes como el cuidado de niños, ancianos y personas con discapacidad. La mayoría de los europeos está de acuerdo en que las empresas deben enfocarse en metas sociales y ambientales, no solo en ganancias.

**Próximo paso** – Casi el 90 por ciento de las personas quieren que sus gobiernos creen leyes y estrategias para apoyar a las organizaciones de la economía social. Esto podría llevar a reglas más fuertes y más recursos para ayudar a crecer a estas organizaciones.

**Frase clave** – Los austríacos donan y hacen voluntariado más que la mayoría de los europeos, mostrando un fuerte apoyo a las causas sociales y al cuidado comunitario.
